importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 19, 2025, and was reported in the context of a major aviation accident at Hong Kong International Airport, affecting public safety and airport operations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The cargo plane skidded off the runway at approximately 3:50 a.m. local time, marking the timeline of the incident and the beginning of the emergency response.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by Turkish carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) during arrival from Dubai, breaking in two.
The aircraft collided with an airport security patrol car, pushing it into the sea, resulting in the deaths of two staff members.
The Boeing aircraft was partially submerged with significant damage, including a snapped tail section and cockpit damage, but all four crew members survived and were treated at local hospitals.
No distress signals were transmitted by the pilots; the Civil Aviation Department reported no emergency communication during approach.
The incident led to the suspension of operations on the north runway, though other runways remained operational, minimizing disruption to over 1,000 daily flights.
The flight was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which operates cargo capacity for major airlines like Emirates; the crew was confirmed safe, with no cargo on board.
Hong Kong International Airport, though one of the world’s busiest, has a rare history of aviation accidents, with the last major one in 1999.
The former Kai Tak Airport was notoriously difficult to land at due to its location in a densely populated area, highlighting the significance of modern airport safety standards.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) during arrival from Dubai at around 3:50 a.m. on October 19, 2025. The aircraft, a Boeing model, broke in two upon departure from the runway, colliding with an airport security patrol car and pushing it into the sea, resulting in the deaths of two staff members. The four crew members on board were unharmed and received medical treatment. No distress signals were reported by the pilots. The airport suspended operations on the north runway while emergency responders, including over 200 personnel, worked to manage the incident. Despite the severity, operations on the other two runways continued, minimizing disruption to over 1,000 daily flights. The flight was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which operates cargo capacity for Emirates, and no cargo was onboard. This incident underscores the rare but serious risk of aviation accidents at one of the world’s busiest and most advanced airports, with historical context provided by past accidents, such as the 1999 China Airlines crash at the old Kai Tak Airport.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
